title: Bonus: Australian Scientist Offers First-Hand Account Of Steve Irwin's Tragic Death
dc:creator: WBUR
description: Australian scientist Jamie Seymour was friends with the famous "Crocodile Hunter," Steve Irwin. He was even there when Irwin was fatally stung by a stingray in 2006. Jamie sat down with Ben to reflect on that experience and Irwin's legacy.
itunes:author: WBUR
itunes:title: Bonus: Australian Scientist Offers First-Hand Account Of Steve Irwin's Tragic Death
itunes:summary: Australian scientist Jamie Seymour was friends with the famous "Crocodile Hunter," Steve Irwin. He was even there when Irwin was fatally stung by a stingray in 2006. Jamie sat down with Ben to reflect on that experience and Irwin's legacy.
itunes:subtitle: Australian scientist Jamie Seymour was friends with the famous "Crocodile Hunter," Steve Irwin. He was even there when Irwin was fatally stung by a stingray in 2006. He sat down with Ben to talk about that experience and Irwin's legacy.

media:content.media:description: In this June 18, 1999 file photo, Steve Irwin, "The Crocodile Hunter" holds a nine-foot female alligator accompanied by his American wife Terri at his "Australia Zoo" in Beerwah, Queensland, Australia. In 2006, Steve Irwin was killed by stingray in the waters off Australia while filming. (Russell McPhedran/AP/File)

content:encoded: Australian scientist Jamie Seymour was friends with the famous "Crocodile Hunter," Steve Irwin. He was even there when Irwin was fatally stung by a stingray in 2006. Jamie sat down with Ben to reflect on that experience and Irwin's legacy.
